reviewText: I very much wanted to like this game. I have enjoyed text-based adventures in the past, and I hoped that this would be a fun way to role-play as my own created hero. Right off the bat, the game doesn't really do anything to explain how it works, or what you are suppose to be doing. So with little direction, I created my character and am offered to perform one of ten actions for the turn". The first action I saw was "go on patrol" (or something similar)
date: so  I went ahead and tried it. I saw nothing. So I tried it again. Still nothing to respond to. So I went and used the training option for a few rounds to build up more points to spend on stats/traits/powers for my character. Then I noticed a button to track down villains. So I spent TEN TURNS trying to track down a single opponent at level 1. Finally
recommended: I managed to find them and start a battle. Unfortunately
hoursPlayed: this is where it got even more confusing. The game battles are determined by "seeds" which seem to be the total offensive 'rolls' of the attacker pitted against the total defensive rolls of the one being attacked. If you score high enough offensively
voteText: you hit; or vice versa for the defending hero/villain. There are several things that affect rolls such as traits
votesFunny: and various other factors. But the problem here is that I honestly have yet to figure out what dictates a hit
column17: or anything else. It seems to cryptic. One time I actually managed to roll a 421 defensively against a roll of 24 from the attacker
column18: and I still got hit for full damage. It simply doesn't make sense to me.\n\nNow all of this could simply be chalked up to me simply not understanding the game fully
column19: but there is NO EXCUSE for my next experience. I made a new character just to test patrols
column20: and gave him balanced stats. I ran him on patrol over 150 times and never found ANYTHING. My character went depressed from lack of motivation from doing nothing
column21:
and that results in a gameover. That was when I decided to quit before I hit two hours so that I could refund the game. Its just poorly done.

Pro's
-------
-You can create a custom hero from a large selection of portraits and move-types

-Seemed to run fine

Con's
-------
-Confusing layout
-Unrealisticly low chance of discovering crimes (at least during the early phase of the game)
-Poor explainations of core game mechanics
-Sloppy combat text descriptions - It just seems as if it presumes to much.

(I have removed the no audio Con. In all fairness
column22:
BGM or Clicker audio is not required by any means for a text-based game to be enjoyable)

_____

After reading some feedback I do realize now that perhaps I would have had a more enjoyable experience had I started a hero at a higher tier so that I could handle and possibly even encounter more villains. But I am sure that the limitations put in place by the lower-ranked hero system are not intentional as it seems to negate any sort of drive to start from the bottom and work your way up; whats a good comic without an origin story?"

reviewText: The only other review on here says the game doesn't explain much, and that's definitely true. On the other hand, the base engine built for this game seems incredibly customizable, think gurps or mutants and masterminds, and I think I'll enjoy the challenge of figuring out the mechanics of the game. I should note that you will absolutely hate this game if you don't enjoy pen and paper games, or are expecting a world you can actually see, instead of read about. If on the other hand you don't mind a lot of reading (and I mean a lot of reading), and you don't mind having to guess at how elements of the game world work, then you can have a lot of fun with this.\n\nAlso, don't go patrolling for your first few turns, there's a gauge on your sheet which says how much criminal activity there is, random patrols don't do so well when there aren't people to patrol for, and you can help with civilian projects/hunt for people instead.
voteText: 84 of 103 people (82%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
The game is badly designed and has very little progression. When you start out you have 2 options grab an existing character or struggle with your own to make an emotionally stable character before they have a breakdown. If you do happen to make one either by exploiting the flaws in the system or pure luck then you are stuck grinding away for any progress. This isn't really even a game but a design your own hero concept on computer without any of the flaws resolved.

Learning the game is a chore for most people as there is no manual or tutorial so while it looks like there is a lot of content but there really isn't. This is more of a fan made concept world for people who wish to play out their fantasies with their favorite superheroes.

Cannot recommend it as there are much better games out there and while they might not give as many customization options at least they work like a sim or another type of game should.

Should you want to create your own world it is possible through this program unlike the others but the system of making heroes doesn't work well. You will end up spending much more time in the editor than actual gameplay and sooner or later just jumping into premade character to mess around for a bit. In order for this to be a good game they will need to overhaul the system to make it more enjoyable or at least put options in to make it more live fast die young rather than breaking people's will to be a superhero.
voteText: 41 of 49 people (84%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I haven't played hours and hours of this game, yet, but I think it's good.
Okay, so that's the simple bit. Now I'll go a bit more in depth.

This game is almost entirely text, but it does come with quite a few images of the characters that are very interesting and well-made. It doesn't have a tutorial, which would have been nice, but it is fairly easy to get the hang of once you know what you're doing.
The default universe/database is fun with a number of comedic references to existing comic book characters.

I do believe that this game would be somewhat improved with a soundtrack and a tutorial, but otherwise it's a good game. You can also go online to find mods for the game including skins and new databases, which is cool (it would be nice if these mods ended up in the Steam Workshop).

Don't be put off from this game. It has a learning curve, and aspects of the game are dictated by luck, but it's great fun.
voteText: 39 of 50 people (78%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
As of the typing of this I've played this 110 hours.  I guess I like it, so here's a review!

Anyone remember Romance of the Three Kingdoms VIII?  That's 8 for you youngsters.  You make a character during the China's war filled Han Dynasty and proceed to do whatever.  Join a lord and fight battles, be a bandit, go farming, wander the lands learning crap, or take over territory to call your own.  Whatever you do, everyone else does their own thing.  Wars can start and end without you being involved in any way.  You're a single fish in a big pond.

That's what I like about this game.  You're a lone super hero in a world full of heroes and villains.  It does practically everything RTK8 does (only without flashy graphics and no sound) and has an awesome hero creation system.  Whoever your favorite hero is, you can make them in this game.  Any combination of powers you can think of can be done.  Think Wolverine would be cool if he could fly and travel through time?  Do it in this game.  What about Batman if he read minds and can split in to 8 other Batmans (Batmen)?  This game can do it.

The game also includes an editor.  You can edit your own hero whenever you like.  I'd suggest moderation when doing that.  Don't max out everything you can.  That'll take away the fun and leave nothing to spend your points upgrading.  I mostly have used it to add relationships.  It's a tad annoying when you can't find someone you are searching for within 30 searches.  Adding a relationship saves time and prevents rage.  Unless you like to rage, then by all means have at it.

reviewText:
The game has potential.  Unfotunately, that's all that it has at this point.  While this is one of the most customizable games I have seen in a long while, customization on its own is hardly enough to carry the title.  The lack of any kind of documenation or tutorial leaves users to flounder about (usually maddingly as one gets defeated right off the bat).  The lack of goals (other than simply leveling up) also is a little bit of a let down.

Finally, I am NOT against text-based games (I'm olde enough to have thoroughly enjoyed Zork...when it was released), this game does not use the text to actually carry the game forward.  With a lack of story, with a lack of goals, and with a lack of direction, the user is left scratching his/her head trying to figure out what is all of this for?"

While I see potential
date: the lack of goals and the complete lack of instruction leave this game a little cold for me."
helpfulPercent: 16 of 17 people (94%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Some of Adam Ryland's other games, such as Total Extreme Wrestling and World Of MMA, are all-time classics. I've spent hundreds of hours on each of them. I don't understand the point of Comic Book Hero: The Greatest Cape though.

You fight villains and level up your hero but you rarely capture or kill the bad guys. If you do capture them, they go to prison and break out after a while. If you kill them, your world gets depopulated, which is a bad thing. The leveling is very slow and feels like a grind, and other heroes around me rarely seem to level up either.

I enjoy the relationship system but it seems like I have to do social meetings over and over again to get the slightest bonuses. Even when I become a close ally of someone, not much seems to change in the game. Same when I become an enemy of a villain. None of it seems to go anywhere.

Unlike Ryland's good games, the world around you doesn't seem to change much, no matter what you do. Without that, I don't know what the purpose of playing is.

EDIT: As a test, I played as Captain Awesome, one of the strongest heroes on the game and deliberately lost to a low level villain called Marquess. Awesome is level ten, Marquess is level three. I lost to him four times. He didn't level up once. I can only assume that villains don't level up at all, and NPC heroes don't either. So the world is completely static. This feels like a completely lifeless game.

reviewText:
Pretty entertaining. Though more fun to add mods to get more characters or add your own; and even then I'm frequently in the editor messing things up such as changing Villains to heros and so to see how things turn out.
Adding superman/girl so far tends to break the game because their weakness should be a type of rock, though the game only allows weaknesses to things like magic, acid, water, wind - none seems to match crypton rock. And then Rogue ends up beating everyone including the hulk due to stealing their powers..

Its a open, non-handholding sandbox game in a world where every hero lives their own lives and has own story.
Each hero performs daily actions: patrolling city, working, resting, dating.. yes.
Villians plot and steal in addition. Natural conflicts occur when the two groups meet up.
You only view your own story mostly with news of other hero/villian actions. Who fought who in your area; who died or were imprisoned, who broke out.. who left teams. (you can start teams too and recruit ohters as leader)

All this freedom does have a slight weakness, as everyone's game will be a DIFFERENT experience. With no linear story the devs cannot control one story everyone follows, so will share different experiences on every game. You may also have designed your hero wrong with non-useful abilities and powers for its current area and end up having a bad game. (eg. water weakness against your human-torch fire-based hero in area where all villans have water based attacks) Fortunately there is always and editor where you can change things ingame.

reviewText:
Listen, I love superhero games and feel there should be more. I would love a game where you can make your own character and sandbox it, like Mass Effect or Skyrim. This... this is not that game. I wanted to give it a chance. I really wanted to like it. However, you will be bored. You spend most of your time tracking villains and not finding them. So maybe you want to search for another hero to help out, well... they are hard to find as well. This was a very disappointing game.

PROS: You can make your own hero and rename the powers.
Modding

CONS: In a city full of supervillians you'll spend a real hour looking for them only to have them beat you.
Text based.
A bit corny, I wished he took the genre more seriously.

This guy should have made the game more like Loren, Amazon Princess. That would have made a killer game. However, all you have is a 'simulator'. How many comics have you read where the hero spends 20 issues tracking a nobody? With heavy heart I cannot recommend this game.

Please do not buy it! This is not a $20 game! It is overpriced. It should be $1 and that is being generous.

reviewText:
This is one of those games where it doesnt do anything that makes you want to shout about it from the rooftops.  However it is very fun if you like text based sims.

basically this game is about, you the player, being a comic writer not a hero.  you are writing your heros story as you play the game.  choices will arise that will affect many things from powers gained or penalties incurred, or even death.  its broken into volumes (levels - described as popularity among readers from 1-10) and chapters (major encounters like battles, death, etc.)

there are 4 ways to start with a hero.  use one that is premade, choose a backstory and have one generated, clone one from the list, or create a custom hero altogether.  i chose the latter myself.

your skills, powers, and attributes are minimal if this is your chosen path.  you can build your hero up from there but it will take time.  if you are looking for a more powerful hero id choose another route.  i kind of liked it.  felt like the birth of a hero and you get to guide him along his story from the very start.

its broken into turns that dont always equate to a chapter as chapters are only major occurences.  you search for baddies or friendlies, visit your friends and allies, patrol, train, etc. etc.  these choices will mold your story step by step.

some of the choices dont always result into anything meaningful however.  for example, patrolling doesnt always result in finding a struggle and searching for other NPCs often times result in an uneventful turn.  this is probably the only major downside imo.  between each turn you get a run down of what other heros and vilians are doing so if you string together a few of these uneventful encounters you find your self clicking through the sea of notifications at times.  not a huge issue, but can get frustrating.

combat take a bit of getting used to.  once you understand it though it can be fun, and frustrating at times.  its not a perfect system but it does the job.  it will create nailbiting fights, but will also create some pretty boring or hairpulling ones as well.  again not perfect, but it does the job.

being text based, the graphics wont excite anyone.  the writing is ok, but wont blow your mind by any means.  i have yet to complete a story so not sure if there is some kind of epic journal somewhere yet, but i dont really expect one.  in fact, i hope i can take my hero on for some time as i have found myself connected to hero in a short time.

there is a great editor in the game and some nice mods floating around as are with most games made by Grey Dog.  if you are the creative type, this is probably a good choice for you if you wish to create your own universe of supers.

if you like these type of games, then you will enjoy this one.  Grey Dog creates some fun games and this one does as well.  for the price is was worth it to me, but i can see why some wont feel the same way.  these games arent for everyone.

tldr:  fun game if you like text based sims.  lots of options and great editor + mods.  wont blow your mind, but shouldnt dissappoint if these games are your thing.

reviewText:
Comic Book Hero: The Greatest Cape:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

At some stage in our lives we have all dreamed of becoming a Superhero and fighting against baddies and their evil crimes! The question is how, did you get your super powers? Were you summoned from the dead by an inexplicable source?  Were you born mutant with some strange powers?  Or you tripped on an object while on a walk in the bush and landed on an Alien Artefact which gave you unforeseen powers?  Or none of that….?  Nah, who needs super powers when you are an expert in martial arts and super-fast!

Comic Book Hero: The Greatest Cape is a text-based adventure / management /simulation genre of game where you play a Superhero who fights crimes. At the start of the game you will have to choose what mode you would like to play. There are 4 modes in total – Role Play (choose an existing Superhero and play as him/her) – Back Story (choose a Superhero with his/her origins and powers but create your own name) – Clone (you have the powers and abilities of the hero you selected but you do not share relationships or teams they have) - Custom (you customize your Superhero from scratch). If it is your first attempt in this genre, I would recommend selecting the mode Back Story to start with. Also, you will have to select what type of difficulty you like to play on, from easy to hard. Easy you will get 10,000 hero points to start with instead of 2,500 if you decide to go the hard way.

The game is setup as turn-based. Each turn you decide what you would like to do; patrol the street to find out if there is any strange activity going on - Track an enemy – Search for a Superhero to form friendship – Train your hero – Recuperate (after a mighty battle is a good Idea) and more. Always have a good look at your Superhero state of mind and make sure he/she is not getting depressed.

The combat system is an aspect that I had a bit of trouble understanding at the start, but as you play it, you will get the hang of it. However, it will feel a bit random at times. It will cost you energy each time you use choose an attack. If your energy is too low but you have Hero points up your sleeve, you can use them to boost your energy back up, but it will cost you a fair wack. Otherwise miss a turn, it will help to regenerate your energy (not much but it will help).  At the end of the battle, you will get Hero points if you are victorious but you will share the points with the people who you fought with. Win the fight by yourself and all points will be yours!

With the Hero points, you will be able to buy new powers or upgrade your Superhero attributes.
Positive:
~~~~~~
-	Stacks of Superheroes to choose from
-	Plenty of powers to add to your character
-	Editor available
Negatives:
~~~~~~~~
-	Combat system a bit random at times
-	No sounds
-	No Achievements / trading cards

If you don’t mind text-based adventure games / management sims, this is an interesting game and worth having a look at.

7/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

MORE THE_CPT_FROGGY REVIEWS HERE

FOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

reviewText:
It's lacking in a lot of areas (multiplayer, modding, villain mode, etc) but what it does have really allows you to immerse your imagination into being a hero.

I've only played as a Custom hero and I can honestly say that the games slow pace and difficulty setting really made me savor every victory against the various villains this game had to offer. Slowly working my up from an obscure hero to a certified legend was exciting! As I increased in strength so did the level of villains I took on, when I got strong enough to take on the biggest baddies and pull out victories against them I literally talked ♥♥♥♥ to my computer screen roleplaying as the hero, gloating over my superiority.


Forming relationships with other heroes was just as interesting as taking on the villains. Apparently the better your relationship the more likely the hero is to show up for a battle you're about to take part in but I honestly can't say that with certainty. It's still enjoyable to build your relationships with other heroes as eventually you gain the ability to form super teams like the Avengers or the Justice League, you can name them whatever you want and have up to 20 members on a team. You also have the ability to form multiple teams.

As of this moment I'm still enjoying the game immensely and my goal is to get every hero/antihero/wilcard in the game to join one of my teams. A silly goal but this game encourages imagination from the player, visualizing how the fights go down and the various shennanigans your character gets up to is most of the fun!

Also since this game is quite difficult for newcomers, I'd like to point out the Editor! It's at the top with all the other options like New Game Load Game etc and once you're in the game with your hero/anti-hero you have the ability to edit your characters everything! It's a fun and easy way to make a godlike character and mess around to get the hang of the game and powers. Have fun!


(If we could get the ability to mod this....OOOOOOOOOOOOO)

reviewText: Fun if you like pen & paper Superhero Rpg games.Mods add alot to the game.Also can use these Mod assets(pictures) and storylines in your own pen & paper games.Relationship element of the game is fun.The changing roster of heroes and villains and their escapades in the various citys(DYNAMIC rogue elements) makes for a great backdrop to your own hero's adventures.Reccomend.

reviewText: I honestly love this game.  Sure, there is a steep learning curve at the beginning, and to understand many of the things you see you kind of have to just poke around the game for a while, but overall it is very similar to a single player pen and paper RPG.  Biggest thing this game could use is a nice little tutorial, because it does assume you are going to play as an established hero to start.  I believe most people will probably be like me and jump straight into the custom hero, and that makes the game kinds hard to start.  Still working out how the social and romance aspects work, but overall I give this a 4 out of 5 stars.

reviewText: The only bad point this game has is not being able to play as a villain. Other than that, the game's a grindfest (something I don't mind as long as the grind doesn't feel tedious,) and also a tool to create your own universes and fill them with heroes and villains. Sure, the creative process takes time, but once you're done getting the right pictures, stats and powers, and crafting the world to your liking, you could play any character of that universe - or try your luck as a nobody" hero who's just starting out.\n\nOne other point that may be seen as a flaw is that NPC heroes/villains don't level up/down as the player does

reviewText:
To be honest, there is a lot to dislike about this game on the surface.  There's little to no instruction on how to play the game and it can get repetitive in the beginning until the real game starts.  Also, the lack of any real conflict between the villains and heroes makes it seem empty a bit.  Finally, the fact that it is unfinished and won't be getting any more updates is frustrating.

Despite it all, I still enjoyed this game.  Maybe it's because I'm a huge superhero fan and willing to overlook it's glaring faults or maybe I'm just touched in the head.  Don't care; had fun.  Especially once I learned how to make my own heroes/villains/worlds/time periods.  That's when the game really opens up, if you're the type that's into that sort of thing.

Still, I'd buy it on sale...

reviewText: I honestly don't know how to review this game and be polite at the same time. I have been playing games for over 20 years, and I don't think I've EVER come across an interface so horribly designed. There are many nice ideas in this game, but that's all they are - ideas. Don't think for a second there's actually a game to be played here.\n\nI really wanted to like this game, so much that I ignored it's low review score. But as it stands, this game is a navigational nightmare, making it unplayable for anyone who wants to remain sane.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I really like this game and can tell I'm going to sink many, many more hours into it than the 6 or so I already have. The amount of customization avaliable is absolutely insane and the text based combat isn't a bother at all (for me at least). However, this game is not without some serious drawbacks, so be wary if you purchase it. For starters there is absolutely no hand holding whatsoever and the lack of a tutorial can obviously be frusturating as many things aren't very clear, but once you start understanding the mechanics of the game it becomes much more fun. My biggest quarrel is with the resolution. I hate how you can't alter it with ease! I would love a way for me to make the game adjustable to multiple different resolutions and a fullscreen mode. This review may seem to contain a lot more negativity than positive information in the review, but I still would definitely give this game a positive review because of it's amazing potential and cool content that already exists! (I would wait for a sale like I did because in the current state I don't think this is a twenty dollar game, but it easily could be with a proper tutorial and if given some attention to the resolution issues)
